channel.title: The Detail on SWIEST - Transcripts · Screenplays · Lyrics
channel.description: Recent content in The Detail on SWIEST - Transcripts · Screenplays · Lyrics

item.title: The Year in Detail | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The Detail’s co-hosts Sharon Brettkelly and Tom Kitchin, and producer Alexia Russell, roll through the highlights of nearly 300 podcasts and long reads in 2023 Transcript

item.title: The Christmas display elves of Queen St | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Every Christmas Auckland’s big department store creates joy and delight for children in Queen St. We meet the people behind the displays. Transcript

item.title: A crossroads for netball | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description As Netball in New Zealand gears up to mark its centenary, strong headwinds are appearing on the horizon. Transcript

item.title: Saving South Dunedin from going under | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description South Dunedin is one of New Zealand’s most densely populated areas but it is also one of the lowest lying. Coming up with ways to save it from repeated flooding is becoming urgent. Transcript

item.title: Sliding backwards on human rights | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description A 75 year old UN declaration still holds sway over New Zealand’s legislation and conduct. But the Human Rights Commission sees threats around the corner. Transcript

item.title: Long Read: The grief bird | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description By Ellen Rykers: The bittern’s eerie, booming call sounds like a lament, a tangi ringing across the marshes. Now, the birds themselves are in trouble Transcript

item.title: COP28's chaotic talkfest on climate change | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description It’s unclear if commentators at COP28 are holding their breaths to see what the Dubai conference will deliver, or because the oil producing country is blanketed in haze. Transcript

item.title: The alcohol conundrum | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description What’s wrong with being a functioning alcoholic? And when booze has such a high visual profile in our society, why is there so much judgement when people fall foul of their own limits? Transcript

item.title: Bulldozing through environmental laws | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description At a time when severe weather events are wrecking the environment, contractors on small building sites ignoring the rules are adding to the problem. Transcript

item.title: What's the fuss over pseudoephedrine? | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description After a 12-year ban that was completely ineffective in stopping the manufacture of methamphetamine, the government is going to allow pseudoephedrine products to be sold over the counter again. Transcript

item.title: When choice fatigue hits charitable giving | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description So many crises, and so many charities to deal with them. Donor confusion has been increasing, which is why eight New Zealand-based organisations have linked up to cut administration costs and get the money to where it’s needed most. Transcript

item.title: Long Read: The Crewe Murders | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description By Kirsty Johnston: The murder of Harvey and Jeannette Crewe in their Pukekawa farmhouse in 1970 remains New Zealand’s most infamous cold case. Transcript

item.title: The insincere marketing that goes from woke to woke-washed | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Some big brands have taken big steps backwards with their images, just as they thought they were jumping on a bandwagon of progressive thought and inclusivity. Transcript

item.title: Judith Collins becomes the minister for everything | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Spies, space and science form just part of the new domain for battle-hardened politician Judith Collins. Transcript

item.title: Disbelief as a smokefree generation slips away | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Anti-smoking researchers are promising a healthy fight against the new government’s moves to repeal world-first legislation on tobacco sales. Transcript

item.title: The deep tech sector dreaming up ways to save the planet | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description A look inside an Auckland building that’s an incubator for the deep tech sector, aimed at finding solutions for some of the world’s biggest carbon-emitting materials. Transcript

item.title: Google: The monopoly we don't want to live without | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Google is the big, intrusive company that we welcome into our lives with open arms because of the way it helps us through our daily lives. Will a ruling from the US say it’s gone too far? Transcript

item.title: Long Read: Weighing the Booker Prize shortlist | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description By Jeremy Rees: I read every book shortlisted for the most prestigious literary award in the world. Here’s what I found. Transcript

item.title: New Zealand's meth flood | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Meth dealers in New Zealand are driving increasingly sophisticated and profitable operations, so much so that police now call them “criminal business entities”. Transcript

item.title: The smothering weed spreading fast and far | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Auckland’s aquatic backyard and prime fishing grounds are weed-deep in trouble from exotic caulerpa, a fast-spreading algae that smothers everything in its path. Transcript

item.title: Striking gold hits obstacles | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Conservation groups, prepare for battle – we’re likely to see more mining applications as the country’s new chief executive promises economic benefits from going underground. Transcript

item.title: Divorce, remarriage, inheritance, and outdated laws | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Family disputes are getting increasingly complex and costly to unravel. There’s agreement on updating the law, but actual changes have stalled. Transcript

item.title: The problems driving congestion charges | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description If congestion charges work to break up gridlock, why don’t we have them in place by now? Transcript

item.title: Long Read: The Badjelly Chronicles | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description By Gemma Gracewood: How New Zealand developed an unique obsession with the baddest witch in all the world. Transcript

item.title: K-Pop dances its way across the globe | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description K-Pop is about dance moves and perfectly presented superstars as much as it is about the music. The phenomenon’s Kiwi fans love it for that. Transcript

item.title: Wellington's microfractures and macrofinances | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Seismic cracks and new earthquake-related infrastructure rules are causing havoc with Wellington City Council’s budgets and long term planning. Transcript

item.title: NZ's screen industry wants a slice of the Netflix pie | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description New Zealand’s $3 billion screen industry could shrivel up without some drastic improvements in funding. One solution is to ask the big streamers to cough up. Transcript

item.title: Pandemic pets now left to their own devices | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Covid lockdowns have left us with a legacy of unwanted and increasingly dangerous dogs. Transcript

item.title: The quiet inquiry | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description New Zealand’s inquiry into how we handled the pandemic has already spoken to hundreds of people of all persuasions, but the work is definitely taking the hush-hush approach. Transcript

item.title: Long Read: Loss of Incidental Connections | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description By Susan Strongman: Retired and living alone in Hamilton, Mum ticks a lot of the boxes that put her at risk of loneliness. Transcript

item.title: Libraries fight to survive under tight council budgets | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description When councils cut their budgets, it’s always libraries that have the spotlight put on them. As staff hours and numbers are cut, librarians are overcoming their reluctance to whisper about the value of their services. Transcript

item.title: Incomplete science deals blow to Ārepa | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description A kiwi health drink with some unique ingredients has been making a splash. But after it promised too much in its marketing it’s been slapped down by food authorities. Transcript

item.title: Why are we waiting? | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Is our MMP electoral system slow and cumbersome, or fair and democratic? Transcript

item.title: Fear and trauma from a world away | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description A Jewish and a Palestinian man both find they’ve been naïve in believing New Zealand to be a safe haven from hatred and abuse. Transcript

item.title: Ka kite for Māori Health Authority? | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The clock is about to be wound back on Labour’s Māori health initiative despite pleas that it should be given more time to prove its worth. Transcript

item.title: Long Read: The straight and narrow | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description By Bill Morris: Ploughing-the epitome of the colonial ‘civilising’ of land-is as fundamental to this country’s history as war and rugby. Perhaps it’s not surprising that we make a sport out of it. Transcript

item.title: Supie's sidelined, so what's next? | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Introducing more competition into the grocery sector will be one of the first, and trickiest, tasks facing the new government. Transcript

item.title: Convenient cities become conspiracy targets | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description How did a vision to make cities more liveable become twisted into a totalitarian dystopia? Transcript

item.title: Gang crackdown about to rev up | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The new government is vowing to take a hard line with gang members, including those with tattoos showing gang affiliations. Transcript

item.title: Ditching the dye | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Grey hair and wrinkles are finally becoming something to celebrate. Transcript

item.title: The gaming games | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Esports players say their sport is more than just time on the couch with a joystick – we have a national team, and it’s heading to global games at the end of the year. Transcript

item.title: Long Read: The MethaneSAT saga | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description By Eloise Gibson: How did New Zealand come to invest $29 million in a Bezos-backed methane satellite space plan? Transcript

item.title: Making the Planet less Lonely | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The book that was for many years a travellers’ bible turns 50 this year. But with instant information available anywhere, how will Lonely Planet keep up? Transcript

item.title: A brainy comic collaboration | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The power and potential of comic books is being realised with a new project at Auckland University. Transcript

item.title: Student radio's cupboards are bare | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Once the juggernaut of student radio, Auckland’s 95bFM is resorting to a fundraising concert to try to clear debt in an age when every commercial station is struggling for funds. Transcript

item.title: Pacific MPs in short supply for this government | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Political representation from the Pasifika community has been lost in an ocean of white faces and blue suits. Does it matter? Transcript

item.title: Long Read: There and back again | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description By Kate Evans: Humans have been puzzling over the mysteries of animal migration and navigation for centuries. Transcript

item.title: Otago's extreme student initiations | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Hazing rituals at Otago University are getting more extreme, with even those all in favour of the student culture asking if they’ve gone too far. Transcript

item.title: The West Coast's surprising shade of blue | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Few pundits flagged the West Coast, birthplace of the Labour Party, to be part of the big blue swing this election. Transcript

item.title: Israel v Hamas: The war without end | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Why do experts have very little hope for a peaceful solution in the Middle East? Transcript

item.title: Election '23: The hangover | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description There’s a lot we still don’t know after election day. Here are the answers to those lingering questions from Saturday night. Transcript

item.title: Covid: Still here, still deadly | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description It’s the unwelcome guest that no one wants to talk about – Covid-19 may be below the radar now, but it hasn’t gone away and is likely to claim 1,000 Kiwi lives this year. Transcript

item.title: Long Read: Is film criticism a blessing or a curse? | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description By Tony Stamp: The art of criticism is being threatened by a new wave of social media-savvy disruptors. Transcript

item.title: Behind the polling booths | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description From preparations that begin two years out, to a double vote count after the polls close, our elections are a massive logistical exercise. Transcript

item.title: The storm over a washed-out walkway | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description It’s one of the most unique and beautiful short walkways in the country, but time has expired on the gentlemen’s agreement that let the public through. Transcript

item.title: Warkworth's seamless manufacturing change | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Sir Russell Coutts has leased his SailGP manufacturing factory to Rocket Lab – and his specialist carbon composite workers are part of the deal. Transcript

item.title: Our messy migration | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Self-serving, messy, and directionless. With record numbers pouring into the country, our immigration policies are under the microscope – and they don’t stand up to scrutiny. Transcript

item.title: When breathing kills | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Air pollution is the invisible killer behind one in every 10 deaths in New Zealand. There’s no safe level of it, but it’s an easy issue to ignore. Transcript

item.title: Long Read: Tairāwhiti's Trauma | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description By Aaron Smale: On the slow destruction and devastating impact of the pine industry on Tairāwhiti. Transcript

item.title: A garden for soul food | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description When living space is tight, a community garden gives residents a place to breathe. Transcript

item.title: Hope and false hope for Alzheimer's sufferers | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Scientists have worked out how brain cells die in Alzheimer’s disease, but there’s caution over starting the celebrations just yet. Transcript

item.title: Disability is this year's forgotten issue | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Few parties have policies on disability issues this election. How can disabled people ensure their voices are heard? Transcript

item.title: The Voice of confusion | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description It’s just a “moderate, tiny proposal” over indigenous representation, but Australia’s The Voice referendum has caused huge uproar. Transcript

item.title: A sometimes summer of sun | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description A change in our three-year La Niña weather pattern will turn the tables on our summer – but don’t think El Niño isn’t also without its issues. Transcript

item.title: Long Read: The food lobby in Aotearoa | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description By Guyon Espiner: How the food industry throws its weight – and its money – around in sport, politics, nutrition, and education. Transcript

item.title: Torn apart by war, kept apart by bureaucrats | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The only chance 18-year-old Afghan refugee Arezo Nazari has of bringing her parents to New Zealand is through the government – and so far, three ministers have turned her down. Transcript

item.title: Helping or harming? Our modern mental health conversations | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description A multi-billion dollar industry has sprung up around mental health and wellness. Have the efforts to raise awareness been too successful? Transcript

item.title: Making our drinking water safe | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The cryptosporidium outbreak in Queenstown highlights the challenges of providing a clean water supply. Why is it so difficult to make our drinking water safe? Transcript

item.title: Recycling the wrong ideas about climate change | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Recycling is not the beginning nor end when it comes to climate change. In fact, it comes way down the list of things you can personally do to help save the planet. Transcript

item.title: Tiny homes, big problems | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description There are a lot of good reasons to downsize to a tiny home. But there are just as many problems in getting started. Transcript

item.title: Long Read: Make voting sexy again | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description By Nadine Anne Hura: If those with the least wealth and privilege understood how much power they held, their votes could really could make a difference. Transcript

item.title: A bright idea for Naseby | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The entire community of Naseby has decided to turn down the lights – and reach for the stars. Transcript

item.title: When a 'wasted vote' isn't wasted | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description If you’re disinterested, despondent or deflated by the election campaign and its daily parade of pointless behaviour, here’s why you shouldn’t miss your opportunity to exercise a little strategy in order to try and engineer a result. Transcript

item.title: Tarras locals gear up for a fight over airport | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Christchurch Airport says it’s premature to try and stop a new airport that’s only just having the groundwork laid; but Tarras locals know what they don’t want. Transcript

item.title: Spinning the numbers while ignoring the threats | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Politicians are spending the election campaign weaving all sorts of financial figures into a cloth that suits their narrative – but there’s another issue on the horizon that would overshadow everything. Transcript

item.title: The burning question on rubbish | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Mass incineration could be a great solution to New Zealand’s increasingly scarce landfill space – or it could be a step backwards environmentally. Transcript

item.title: Long Read: Turning the tide | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description A team of New Zealanders and Tongans have just carpeted a remote Tongan island with poisoned bait, hoping to eradicate rats. Transcript

item.title: Liam Lawson's Formula One breakthrough | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description New Zealand’s tenth Formula One driver is a 21-year-old from Pukekohe. Transcript

item.title: The dark twists and crazy turns of Whangārei's big cat park | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The lions and tigers are ready to roar again as Whangārei’s Kamo Wildlife Sanctuary re-opens it doors on Saturday. But the park has a troubled past – and its future is uncertain. Transcript

item.title: Landlords versus tenants | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description There are horror stories on both sides of the landlord/tenant divide, but how do the laws of the country ensure a fair balance between the rights of both? Transcript

item.title: Gender equality: Are we there yet? | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Three exciting world cups on New Zealand soil have boosted coverage of women’s sport stratospherically – and women are now far more visible in public life. When can we say these ‘firsts’ are normal? Transcript

item.title: Winston Peters rides again | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Gone in 2020, washed up and out of the political scene? Not just yet. Assumptions over the demise of Winston Peters and New Zealand First have ignored the old adage – never rule him out. Transcript

item.title: Long Read: What happened to Wellington – Live? | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description By Janhavi Gosavi: Once the shining example for community pages, many followers are growing concerned by its new owner’s approach. Transcript

item.title: The most privileged chair in sport | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description We’re about to get an earful of commentary as the Rugby World Cup kicks off. What’s it like to sit in the big chair at the biggest games? Transcript

item.title: Policing in a new era of crime | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description New Zealand’s criminal landscape is changing, and our police force is having to make adjustments. Transcript

item.title: New Poseidons zoom in on illegal fishers | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description New Zealand’s new Poseidon P-8A has clocked its first official mission: a multi-national operation north-west of Fiji to catch illegal fishing boats. Transcript

item.title: Our Pasifika Rugby World Cup teams | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The Tongan, Samoan and Fijian rugby teams have made huge strides on the world stage. What can we expect from them this World Cup? Transcript

item.title: Quest for answers over three year old's death | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Paul Jones hasn’t let up in his drive to get answers over his three year old son’s death – but in spite of multiple investigations, the truth appears to be no closer. Transcript

item.title: Long Read: Our renewable power struggle | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description By George Driver: Millions of panels could soon be erected across thousands of hectares of the country as an unprecedented solar-farm boom begins. Transcript

item.title: The renaissance of girl power | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The pop culture dollar is being laid down on Barbie and Taylor Swift, as young women not in the market for a mortgage splash their joy around. Transcript

item.title: India's high-science, low-cost space programme | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description After India’s successful landing on the south pole of the moon, there’s hope the West will stop seeing the country as a land of “snake charmers and elephants”. Transcript

item.title: Villa Maria: The dismantling of a legacy | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The saga of Villa Maria wines involves valuable land, an iconic brand, legal action and millions of dollars in dispute. Transcript

item.title: Backsliding in the battle against pest species | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Conservation projects across the country risk losing progress as money gets tighter and budgets are slashed. Transcript

item.title: Tough times brewing for the craft beer industry | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description They say beer is recession-proof, but two of the country’s well-known craft breweries are facing an uncertain future. Transcript

item.title: Long Read: The new Golden Age of rail | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description By Theo Macdonald: Long-distance rail travel is in for a revival in New Zealand — eventually. And you don’t have to be a nostalgia buff, trainspotter or climate-action protester to see why. Transcript

item.title: Migrant worker advocates alarmed by increasing calls for help | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Advocates for migrant workers are alarmed as more and more people come to them for help, because the jobs they’ve been promised haven’t eventuated. Transcript

item.title: Theatre's back, but can it continue to thrive? | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Audiences are returning to theatres, but the future is uncertain for university-level theatre education. Transcript

item.title: After a summer of cyclones, are we ready for a summer of wildfires? | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Scenes of mass destruction in Greece and Hawaii have shown us just how serious wildfires are. Transcript

item.title: Who should teach kids about sex and relationships? | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Most parents find it awkward to talk about, but who should take the lead when it comes to educating kids about sex and relationships? Transcript

item.title: The last NZ company weaving our wool | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The Detail visits New Zealand’s last commercial wool weaver, Inter-Weave, to find out how they’re helping keep the wool industry alive. Transcript

item.title: Long Read: Weaponised | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description By Kate Evans: With each generation, predators and prey refine their aggressive weapons and defensive armour. Transcript

item.title: The future will be riskier – how will insurance keep up? | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description When a natural disaster destroys your home, who should foot the bill? The government, private insurers, or you? Transcript

item.title: Off or on? The debate over GST on fruit and veg | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description It’s popular with the voters, but not with the experts. The Detail takes a closer look at the debate about Labour’s GST plans. Transcript

item.title: Is fish the new farming frontier for New Zealand? | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The government has a goal to grow aquaculture to a $3 billion-a-year industry. But red tape – and red flags – stand in the way. Transcript

item.title: Capitalising on New Zealand's football fever | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The FIFA World Cup has captured the attention of plenty of New Zealanders. How do we keep them interested, and invested, in women’s football once the tournament’s over? Transcript

item.title: Why don't we talk about postnatal depression? | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Maternal mental health is another one of those hidden “women’s issues” that we don’t talk about enough. Now it’s in the spotlight for the most awful of reasons. Transcript

item.title: Long Read: What happened when two young Jehovah’s Witnesses quit the church | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description By Anusha Bradley: After leaving the Jehovah’s Witnesses, Brad Miller and Cassie Dean were cut off from almost everyone they’d ever known. Transcript

item.title: Taking the public pulse with political polls | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The polls are showing a tight race between the two major parties as we inch closer to October’s election. But can we trust them? Transcript

item.title: How NZ's paid parental leave stacks up | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description We like to think we’re pretty progressive, but can New Zealand do more to support parents in the workplace? Transcript

item.title: Public private partnerships and big infrastructure projects | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The Detail weighs up the pros and cons of public private partnerships in big infrastructure projects. Transcript

item.title: The woes of wool | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Wool was once the backbone of our agriculture industry, but now farmers are struggling to make a buck from it. What happened? Transcript

item.title: The new therapeutic products law: What is it? | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description It’s been decades in the making, but there will be major changes to the way we regulate medicines, medical devices and natural health products. Transcript

item.title: Long Read: Immaculate | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description By Dave Hansford: Meet New Zealand’s lawn addicts, who can be found in the weekend perfecting their ‘outdoor carpet’. Transcript

item.title: The charismatic kākāpō is booming, but its friends need help | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Having kākāpō in the North Island wilderness again is an historic win for our native manu, but conservationists say other species are at risk of falling through the cracks. Transcript

item.title: The perilous state of the Far North's roads | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The Far North’s roads are in a perilous state – and the fix-up job is mammoth in scale. Transcript

item.title: The feud between our two big weather forecasters | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description MetService and NIWA are both government agencies. Why are they competing with one another? Transcript

item.title: Taking flight: The post-pandemic travel boom | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Thinking about booking that long-awaited overseas trip? International travel is back and bigger than ever. Transcript

item.title: Banks' endless battles with scammers | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Bank scams are rising exponentially, so much so that $183 million has gone out of New Zealanders’ accounts over the last year. Transcript

item.title: Long Read: The Gloriavale employment case | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description By Jean Edwards: Raised to be meek and submissive in a world dominated by men, six former Gloriavale women have won an extraordinary legal victory. Transcript

item.title: The home detention solution | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description After Auckland’s CBD shooting the knives were out for home detention sentences – but is it the justice system we should be pointing at, or is the problem more deeply-rooted? Transcript

item.title: KiwiSaver as a slush fund | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description It’s their own money – so why shouldn’t hard-up students be allowed to use their KiwiSaver when faced with the tough task of coming up with a bond for their rental? Transcript

item.title: When a graphic warning is not enough | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Should the media be self-censoring its court reporting of the Dickason triple murder trial as the gory details unfold? Transcript

item.title: A sporting empire starts to crumble | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Victoria’s decision to pull out of hosting the 2026 Commonwealth Games after a budget blowout shines light on the huge amount of money it takes for these sporting extravaganzas. Transcript

item.title: Setting prisoners up for failure | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description There’s a silent sentence faced by prisoners just out of jail – one that makes it hard for them to get back on their feet without resorting to crime again. Transcript

item.title: Long Read: Procurement Without Purpose | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description By Nikki Mandow: The government spent $51.5 billion of taxpayer money on buying stuff last year. The criteria for how they spend it have had a shake-up. Transcript

item.title: The zing zazz factor in a slogan | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description As the political parties reveal their slogans for the election campaign, we look at who and what makes a catchphrase sing, Transcript

item.title: Healthy Homes remain an uphill battle | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description There are five basic standards to be met before landlords can get their Healthy Homes tick. Why do so many seem to be slipping through the cracks? Transcript

item.title: The dangers of our productivity slide | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description New Zealand’s slow slide into poor productivity isn’t just a cultural quirk – it means we miss out when it comes to competition and trade opportunities. Transcript

item.title: Social media's new revolution | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Two decades after Facebook.com changed our lives, social media is going through another big upheaval. Transcript

item.title: The power of a well-designed uniform | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Whether it’s a corporate refresh with more cultural considerations, or a new version of a sporting uniform steeped in history, what our high profile teams wear matters. Transcript

item.title: Long Read: The Flames of Our Shame | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description By Max Rashbrooke: While the fatal fire at Loafers Lodge has reinforced calls for greater scrutiny of boarding houses, the warning signals have been around for years. Transcript

item.title: Matariki's link in a chain of star stories | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description We call this star cluster Matariki – but the Seven Sisters myth is told all over the world, in startlingly similar fashion. Could it be our oldest story? Transcript

item.title: Ukraine's cluster bombs will leave a hideous legacy | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The US is sending cluster bombs to Ukraine in a move it hopes will shorten the war – how do they work, and why has the move prompted an uproar from human rights workers? Transcript

item.title: Safe or septic – Japan's nuclear wastewater dumping | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Japan has made assurances the wastewater it’s dumping in the Pacific is safe – but not everyone is convinced. Transcript

item.title: Heroes in the spotlight at White Island trial | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The WorkSafe prosecution over the Whakaari eruption begins today – and some of the heroes of that dreadful day are in the spotlight. Transcript

item.title: Long Read: Bone Hunters | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description By George Driver: An ancient lake bed in St Bathans is revealing New Zealand’s mysterious past. Transcript

item.title: Why city centres are going car-free | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Auckland, Dunedin, and now Wellington – does pedestrianisation solve problems, or create them? Transcript

item.title: 'A slow-moving disaster': Rotorua lakes full to bursting | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Months and months of heavy rain means many of the lakes around Rotorua are reaching levels not seen in 50 years, flooding nearby boat ramps, playgrounds and properties. Transcript

item.title: The impact of the Hollywood writers' strike on NZ | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Hollywood writers have been striking for three months’ now – and there’s no resolution in sight. Half a world away, the strike’s having an impact on the screen industry here in New Zealand, too. Transcript

item.title: What it takes to get a road back open | The Detail

item.description: Podcast Description Research suggests anywhere between 10 and 30 percent of people who get Covid-19 end up developing Long Covid. What happens if that impacts your ability to work? Transcript

item.description: Podcast Description Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern has called the security deal between China and Solomon Islands “gravely concerning” - but does New Zealand really need to be worried? Transcript

item.title: Democracy denied? Why commissioners replace councillors | The Detail

item.title: The Detail is coming back | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The Detail will be back in action from Monday, September 13 Transcript

item.title: The Detail in lockdown mode | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The Detail will be switching to written explainers while our Auckland-based team is locked down in Level 4. Catch us on RNZ and Newsroom’s websites. Transcript

item.title: Downplaying the arts at school | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Changes planned for the NCEA art curriculum have teachers and the art world worried about the down-grading of the subject. Transcript

item.title: An ideological switch that led to our housing crisis | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Data on housing is surreal if you own a home, depressing if you don’t. How did we get to this stage? Transcript

item.title: Futility and despair in Afghanistan | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description In Afghanistan the Taliban is taking control again, even as US military planes leave the tarmac in Kabul. Now the war is being compared to Vietnam in its futility. Transcript

item.title: Immigration - who's in, who's out, who's waiting? | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description There’s a queue for the queue - New Zealand’s immigration process is a nightmare made worse by Covid-19 restrictions. We look at who’s locked out, and why people we need are leaving the country Transcript

item.title: MMA is the combat sport sweeping the world | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Why is the world going mad for mixed martial arts? Sharon Brettkelly goes along to an Auckland gym to find out more. Transcript

item.title: How much climate catastrophe can one world absorb? | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description How much doom, gloom and catastrophising can the world take? We boil down the latest big climate change report. Transcript

item.title: Long Covid short on research | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Between 10 and 30 percent of Covid patients go on to develop Long Covid, a crippling illness with up to 114 symptoms. They’re not happy with the level of research being conducted on it, so they’re fundraising to do their own. Transcript

item.title: Arming the police - is it a step NZ wants to take? | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Gangs with guns; the fatal shooting of an officer in West Auckland; a changing attitude from front line police on firearms. Should we be arming our force? Transcript

item.title: Greenwashing as a marketing tactic | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Companies are increasingly claiming to be ’eco’ - their products are good for the planet - but how true are these environmental claims? And how much is just greenwashing? Transcript

item.title: There is a group guarding NZ's media freedom | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Journalists in New Zealand don’t tend to get shot or jailed for doing their jobs - but they do face some impediments in collecting information. That’s when the Media Freedom Committee is watching. Transcript

item.title: Plans to close NZ's only oil refinery, Marsden Pt | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Marsden Pt shareholders will vote today on a proposal to shut down New Zealand’s only oil refinery, slashing hundreds of jobs. Transcript

item.title: Banning conversion therapy | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Not many people would argue against legislation banning conversion therapy - but there is a lot of devil in the detail. Transcript

item.title: The issues with making Auckland's waterfront wondrous | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Hundreds of millions has been poured into developing Auckland’s waterfront, and there’s more mega-funding to come. Is it being spent in the right place? Transcript

item.title: Why the government's muscling in on the water business | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Crumbling pipes, polluted beaches, bugs in drinking water … something has to be done about the nation’s ageing water infrastructure. But is Three Waters the right solution? Transcript

item.title: Why New Zealand is importing coal by the shipload | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description How can New Zealand be importing massive amounts of coal when we are supposedly on a journey towards 100 percent renewable energy? The answers are complex. Transcript

item.title: The case against Uber - when is a contractor really a worker? | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Unions are heading to the Employment Court taking action over Uber’s drivers - asking the question when a ‘contractor’ is really a ‘worker’, and should be offered worker benefits. Transcript

item.title: An Olympic-sized argument over women's sport uniforms | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Too short, too skimpy, badly designed, or just uncomfortable - women have for too long been on the receiving end of uniform rules where one size doesn’t fit all. Transcript

item.title: The ethics and costs of saving wild animals | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Why do New Zealanders get so invested in saving wild animals that strand themselves? Is it worth spending thousands on getting them back where they belong? Transcript

item.title: Tackling the plague of liquor stores | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description New Zealanders have very easy access to alcohol, and the choices are growing. But communities worried about the harm it’s causing face big hurdles to stop liquor stores proliferating. Transcript

item.title: Looking towards Africa for trade | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description We’ve been told New Zealand needs to take some of those trade eggs out of China’s basket - and Africa is looking wide open after nations signed a continent-wide pact. But there are difficulties. Transcript

item.title: Drawing a line under Auckland's America's Cup | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Financially it was a lemon the moment Covid closed the borders - so how did Auckland do when it came to hosting the America’s Cup? Was it worth it? And should we do it again? Transcript

item.title: The MIQ nightmare | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Desperate kiwis are paying thousands for clever computer operators to get them a space in MIQ, because booking a spot is proving impossible for ordinary travellers. Transcript

item.title: Political moves pushing the path of Covid-19 | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Three closely aligned nations, three different political approaches, and three very different results when it comes to the path taken by the pandemic. Transcript

item.title: Taxing the big tech companies | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Everyone has to pay their fair share of tax - but worldwide, the big tech multi-nationals have been getting away with paying far less than others. There are plans to change that. Transcript

item.title: The sky high cost of living in New Zealand | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Inflation’s hit a 10 year high, and although fuel and houses are largely to blame, the food that we grow in abundance is expensive. Why? Transcript

item.title: Wide open targets - the elderly and banking scams | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Elderly people are being targeted by scammers in heart-breaking numbers. They rarely get their money back, and often they’re too ashamed to admit to having been sucked in. Transcript

item.title: Splitting the difference - our divorce laws | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Our divorce laws are 40 years old - and there’s a renewed push to change them to reflect the realities of the 21st century. Transcript

item.title: Behind nurses' anger over wages | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Nurses have more industrial action planned as frustration with shortages and pay boil over - what’s behind the anger? Transcript

item.title: Our faltering hospitality model | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The Restaurant Association has a long wish list for the government to help its labour shortage situation - but does it need to look internally at the wages and conditions of hospitality workers? Transcript

item.title: The science of beating the drug testers in sport | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Is a sports world without doping an impossible aspiration? David Howman, director-general of the World Anti-Doping Agency, talks drugs and testing. Transcript

item.title: The Covid disaster hammering Fiji | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description While New Zealand and the Cook Islands are bubbling away, the Covid-19 situation in what used to be our biggest Pacific tourism destination, Fiji, is horrifying - and out of control. Transcript

item.title: The Covid Olympics are nearly here | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The Tokyo Olympics might have been delayed a year but somehow it’s still snuck up on us - here’s the rundown on the New Zealand team. Transcript

item.title: Waste minimisation efforts slow to take hold | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The consequences of a wasteful Kiwi lifestyle are getting harder to ignore. Our landfills are filling fast and it’s getting more difficult to find new sites. We do have waste minimisation levers, but change is slow. Transcript

item.title: China is the relationship we don't understand | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description RNZ’s Red Line podcast sees two journalists dip their toes into unknown waters - our carefully balanced relationship with China. Transcript

item.title: The booming problem of construction waste | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The building boom is in full force - but with it comes an ugly side effect. Construction waste is an increasing problem. Transcript

item.title: The horror of Lake Alice | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description No one has ever been held to account for the decades of abuse and torture suffered by children at the Lake Alice psychiatric unit. Now, survivors have told their stories. Transcript

item.title: Re-learning history in Aotearoa | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description History won’t be re-written, but it will be re-learned and taught under the new New Zealand history curriculum. Transcript

item.title: Leaving Gloriavale | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description After 50 years of a closed community on the West Coast, more and more people are leaving Gloriavale. Transcript

item.title: Dome Valley's tipping point | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The Dome Valley dump has planning approval as Auckland hunts for its next rubbish disposal option - but the very real need for a new site is coming up against both environmental and intangible objections. Transcript

item.title: Barriers everywhere for disabled people | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Unsuitable housing, carless city centres, cars parked on the footpath are issues that draw complaints from able bodied people - but if you’re disabled they can have a dramatic impact on your life. Transcript

item.title: The Day of the Vaccine | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description On Wednesday morning, at the same time as news filtered out of a positive Covid-19 case going on a tiki-tour of Wellington, an operation was being executed with military precision at a retirement village in the Auckland suburb of Remuera. The Detail’s Emile Donovan went along to see how an operation like this is run; how residents are feeling about it; and talk about how the 70-plus demographic has first-hand experience of the difference a vaccine can make.

item.title: Bringing back Winston | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description NZ First is the enigma of New Zealand politics. From positions of pivotal power in governments to periods in the political wilderness. The party’s chances of a return to its glory days seem to rest, as they always do, with its long-time leader Winston Peters. Transcript

item.title: Franz Josef fights for survival | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The South Westland town of Franz Josef has survived floods and earthquakes but the lack of international tourists due to border restrictions has forced many of the town’s businesses into closure or hibernation. Transcript

item.title: A modular solution to the housing crisis | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description There’s a factory in Christchurch that could help solve the housing crisis by churning out modular homes - but a reluctance to adopt this building method means its future is unclear. Transcript

item.title: New Zealand's soaring space industry | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description There’s so much happening in New Zealand’s space industry it’s hard to keep up. There’s more to it than just Rocket Lab - it’s bigger than the wine industry - and it’s growing fast. Transcript

item.title: The minefield of portraying real life tragedy on screen | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Action to stop a film being made before it’s even clear what it will be about is a reflection of increased awareness about race, identity and place across the globe. Transcript

item.title: The secrecy and fuzziness around political donations | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Our rules and regulations over political donations are fuzzy - and most of our politicians are getting tripped up by them. Is it time to make those laws more transparent? Transcript

item.title: Small homes, big ambitions | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description It’s not just the big cities suffering from affordable housing issues - but the more remote areas of the country are getting no help, even if they’re willing to help themselves. Transcript

item.title: Housing the mentally ill when the roof is caving in | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description In a time when the country is concentrating on well-being, our mental health facilities are crumbling and overcrowded. Transcript

item.title: SNAs - the green move that cuts farmers deep | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Moves to protect New Zealand’s biodiversity have West Coast farmers feeling under attack as they’re dictated to over what they can do with their land. Are they carrying the can for the rest of us? Transcript

item.title: Speaking Kiwi - how our accents are changing | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The New Zealand accent is a potpourri of international diversity, and it continues to evolve. Transcript

item.title: Is this the death of the post-match presser? | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Tennis star Naomi Osaka’s withdrawal from the French Open on mental health grounds may have cracked open the door for a change in the way we conduct post-match media conferences. Transcript

item.title: Why has the Wuhan lab leak theory re-emerged? | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The Covid-19 Wuhan lab leak theory has re-emerged and appears to have sparked the curiosity of the US President. We look at why, and what the likelihood is of that being the case. Transcript

item.title: How vaping can be a smokefree weapon | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Vaping has been touted as a game-changing tool to help smokers quit - but it also has its downsides. Transcript

item.title: The slow-moving wheels of cycling infrastructure | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Our big cities are supposed to be getting more cycling friendly - but progress is slow and there is a wall of road users who would rather bicycles just disappeared. Transcript

item.title: A grand plan for a company town | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Sleepyhead manufacturer the Comfort Group has a grand plan to build a company town in a rural Waikato location. But is it really such a good idea? Transcript

item.title: The need for Māori housing | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description There was a lot of money for Māori housing and infrastructure in the Budget - $730 million in total. But what is Māori housing, and how will the money be used? Transcript

item.title: Dissecting the sensation-seeking personality | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Kiwi motor racing champion Scott Dixon is a sensation-seeker - but not an adrenaline junkie. Meet the man who looked inside his mind. Transcript

item.title: The strange (and sexist) language of cryptocurrency | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description How on earth do you explain cryptocurrency? Not even those with their head in the game really understand it all. Transcript

item.title: Operating in the dark - Waikato DHB's cyber nightmare | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The cyber attack that took down Waikato DHB’s health system and plunged it into chaos Transcript

item.title: Defective or incompetent? The James Hardie case | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The massive James Hardie court case on now is the latest in decades of leaky building issues. Transcript

item.title: The changing room pervert who hid behind suppression rules | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Uncovering the secret of how a pervert hid his criminal prosecution and became the boss of a crown entity. Transcript

item.title: The alpine hero with a dark past | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Willi Huber was a champion of Mt Hutt’s ski field developments, and a popular local. But it wasn’t until he died that the full horror of his past was revealed. Transcript

item.title: An Olympics like no other - if it goes ahead | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description It’s just nine weeks before the Tokyo Olympics are due to open - but if they go ahead, they’ll look and sound very different to games in the past. Transcript

item.title: The threat hanging over our thriving gaming industry | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description New Zealand has a thriving gaming industry - it’s a genuine career path and we have great talent. But a tax sweetener across the Tasman risks pulling the rug from underneath it all. Transcript

item.title: Wellington is getting short of good days | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description You can’t beat Wellington on a good day - but Wellington’s good days are getting few and far between. Transcript

item.title: Has the Christchurch Call made any progress? | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Has the Christchurch Call made any progress or has the whole thing descended into a talk fest? Transcript

item.title: Laurel Hubbard - lifting for history | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Laurel Hubbard is a reluctant trailblazer, a pioneer for transgender women - but all she wants to do is lift weights. Transcript

item.title: What is He Puapua? | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description A look at what’s in the aspirational He Puapua document, currently being used to stir racial disharmony. Transcript

item.title: Fair Pay Agreements bring a shift in industrial relations | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Details have been released about arguably the biggest shift in industrial relations in 30 years - what are Fair Pay Agreements all about? Transcript

item.title: Trawling for the truth about fishing | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description A new Netflix programme - we’re not calling it a documentary - is putting people world wide off eating fish. But how much of the message was massaged? Transcript

item.title: Making a side hustle work | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Need an extra bit of cash? Here’s a look at whether side hustles are worth it. Transcript

item.title: Beneath the joyful job stats | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The unemployment rate has defied the expectations of economists, banks and Treasury. Is it hiding the reality of the job situation, or did the wage subsidy save us? Transcript

item.title: Pay freezing out your traditional voter base | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Labour’s announcement of a public service wage freeze took everyone by surprise. Was it a party taking aim at its traditional support base, or a minister losing control of the narrative? Transcript

item.title: The hills are alive - with rabbits | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Once again rabbits are on the verge of causing an ecological disaster in parts of New Zealand that will cost us hundreds of millions. Transcript

item.title: Musing on mediocrity | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Celebrate being average. After all, it’s not terrible. Transcript

item.title: Treading a line between hate speech and free speech | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Long awaited reforms on hate speech have gone before Cabinet - and they’re stirring up unease and discontent. Transcript

item.title: The Rich List - with added philanthropy | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The post-Covid rich list is different to NBR’s previous yearly efforts. In 2021, ranking wealthy New Zealanders also means measuring what they give back. Transcript

item.title: Watching by remote as the 'invisible terrorist' hits India | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The Covid-19 crisis in India is so bad it’s been called the ‘invisible terrorist’. It’s also split families in New Zealand and is causing huge heartache. Transcript

item.title: The secrets of obituary writing | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description An obituary is about life, not death. Writing them is a special art. Transcript

item.title: Why it costs so much to build a house | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Much has been said about New Zealand’s construction costs contributing to our housing crisis. But there are reasons for soaring prices - and no easy solutions. Transcript

item.title: Are Amazon's tax funded benefits worth it? | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Why do we pay mega-subsidies to international movie giants to come to New Zealand to film? Is it really worth it? Transcript

item.title: The legacy of the Waikeria Prison riots | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The Waikeria Prison fires are out, the excitement’s died down, the protesters charged. But that’s not the end of the repercussions, with three inquiries underway and civil actions launched. Transcript

item.title: Our bold health system shakeup | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The government’s newly announced health plan heralds a massive change in the system. But commentators say its success depends on what’s in the detail. Transcript

item.title: Electoral upheaval in Samoa as vote makes history | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Nearly two weeks after voting, Samoans still don’t know if their leader of 22 years will be ousted by his former deputy. Transcript

item.title: New moves in the never-ending battle against tobacco | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description A new skirmish in the war against tobacco aims to stub out a whole new generation of smokers. Transcript

item.title: The road bumps in our vaccination rollout | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Trans-Tasman quarantine-free flights are back on - as New Zealand’s vaccination rollout’s been described as shambolic, and Australia’s as a failure. Transcript

item.title: The lasting, shameful legacy of the Dawn Raids | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The Dawn Raids of the 1970s carry a shameful legacy to this day - and those who haven’t forgotten, want an apology. Transcript

item.title: Merging media - a commercial and publicly funded stew | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The biggest shift in public broadcasting is being mulled over by a government-appointed group. But is such a unification desirable, or even necessary? Transcript

item.title: How Facebook's algorithm is changing the world | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Facebook protests that its new algorithm that curates your newsfeed is just a mirror reflecting yourself back at you. If that’s the case, says one digital expert, it’s a funhouse mirror. Transcript

item.title: The battleground in paradise over a Waiheke marina | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description A marina at picturesque Kennedy Point on Waiheke Island is the scene of a massive battle - and work has started in spite of a looming Supreme Court decision. Transcript

item.title: Does a sex offender register really keep children safe? | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description No one would argue against a Child Protection Act - but is a register for child sex abusers actually protecting children? Transcript

item.title: Anti-Asian sentiment in NZ - it's real, it's everywhere | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The spotlight being shone on anti-Asian attacks in America is spilling over to New Zealand, and has highlighted the fact that such sentiments lurk beneath the surface here too. Transcript

item.title: The back-firing probability of rent controls | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description There’s been much speculation that the recent housing announcement could prompt landlords who feel targeted to put up rents. Now there’s counter-talk of rent controls. How would it work? Transcript

item.title: Managing China's theft of NZ's SunGold kiwifruit | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Chinese growers are stealing the kiwifruit we stole from them in the first place, along with the varietal secrets New Zealand holds the rights to. Zespri has a novel plan to combat that. Transcript

item.title: Keeping Pasifika rugby talent | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Pasifika rugby has been the world’s poor cousin for too long. Could a new plan help retain players and see the island game thrive? Transcript

item.title: Productivity, money and wealth - not all the same | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description New Zealand’s “productivity” figures aren’t great and are artificially inflated by rampaging house prices. Toss in wellbeing and the picture looks murky. Transcript

item.title: City bees and their rescuers | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Sharon Brettkelly takes a trip with bee rescuer Jessie Baker to look at the urban beehives that are buzzing away on city rooftops. Transcript

item.title: The Speaker row - should Trevor Mallard step down? | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Trevor Mallard, the arbiter of Parliament’s house rules, is ironically not one to follow the rule book. Transcript

item.title: Turning the taps on with fluoride | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The decision over fluoridation of the country’s water supplies has been handed over to the Director-General of Health. Why is this issue so divisive that it’s been taken out of the hands of councils? Transcript

item.title: The think tanks that help shape public policy | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Under the surface of public discourse lurk a bunch of mysterious organisations who are major players in shaping public policy. Transcript

item.title: Science journalist Alison Ballance hangs up her boots | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description With more than a thousand conservation stories under her waterproof parka, science journalist Alison Ballance is retiring from RNZ’s Our Changing World programme. Transcript

item.title: The next unfathomable currency - NFTs | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description NFTs - non-fungible tokens -are the latest crypto wonder. It seems unfathomable but people are willing to spend huge amounts acquiring them. Transcript

item.title: Tipping the scales in favour of first home buyers | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Has the government managed to remove stumbling blocks for first home owners with its policy announcements yesterday? Or is the basic problem that houses are just too expensive? Transcript

item.title: NZ caught in a tech war between China and the US | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The New Zealand technology sector is booming - but there are rocky shoals ahead. Among them, getting caught in a US-China tech war; and unwittingly contributing to human rights abuses. Transcript

item.title: Drinking (milk) to economic recovery | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description When the Chinese were told to drink milk to stay healthy and recover from the Covid-19 pandemic, New Zealand’s dairy farmers celebrated. The Global Dairy Trade, explained. Transcript

item.title: Our America's Cup - the next steps | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The champagne’s been mopped up, the sailors are recovering from their victory celebrations - what’s the next step for the America’s Cup? Transcript

item.title: Imagining a monarchy-free Aotearoa | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description After the Markle Debacle and Andrew’s murky associations, you couldn’t blame Aotearoa for saying goodbye to the Crown. But what would a queen-free country look like constitutionally? Transcript

item.title: The Pharmac compromise | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Pharmac’s generic drug swap for epilepsy treatment saved $30 million over five years. But for some patients, the consequences were nightmarish. Transcript

item.title: Latin lovers mourn language loss | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description What’s the point in learning a dead language like Latin? It’s been struck off the NCEA list, but its loss will be mourned by many who say it lives on in everyday English, and it’s vital to some professions. Transcript

item.title: Former MP now peddling dubious 'health' supplements | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Fallen politician Jami-Lee Ross has turned his hand to selling “health” supplements with dubious benefits. It’s an industry that’s thinly regulated and barely policed. Transcript

item.title: Talking to the Prime Minister | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Mike Hosking’s made the most of Jacinda Ardern’s decision to ditch him - spinning it as her running for the hills. But what gave him unfettered access in the first place, and did he abuse the privilege? Transcript

item.title: New Zealand's mills are in trouble | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Our wood processing industry is in distress, largely run over by China’s demand for raw logs to provide work for its own people and factories. Why isn’t there more support for the few sawmills we have left? Transcript

item.title: Society on beyond Dr Seuss | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Is the move to stop publishing six Dr Seuss books another example of cancel culture - or an acknowledgement that we’ve moved on from a more insensitive past? Transcript

item.title: The passion and pain over Māori wards | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The subject of Māori wards on local bodies brings out both passionate support and angry opposition. Transcript

item.title: An end at last to the dirty politics saga | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description No one expected the level of intensity and brazenness used by a blogger, a former politician and a PR man in the saga that became known as “dirty politics”. Transcript

item.title: Rules, messages, Covid and confusion | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Someone broke the rules to put Auckland in Level 3 and there has been a clamour for punishment. But the situation isn’t black and white. Is our covid messaging still appropriate? Transcript

item.title: Lockdown loneliness | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Being locked down also means for many people being locked out of meaningful face to face interactions - for them, Level 3 is a tense and frustrating time. Transcript

item.title: When satellites become star pollution | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Elon Musk’s Starlink satellites are a wondrous sight - and also a slightly disturbing one. How many foreign objects can we fit into the night sky before they start crashing into each other? Transcript

item.title: NZ's declining birth rate is changing our world | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description New Zealand’s plummeting birth rate means we have some serious planning to do. Transcript

item.title: How tasty is the My Food Bag IPO offer? | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The My Food Bag IPO this week looks like a mouth watering offer - but the proof of the pudding is in the eating. Transcript

item.title: Jake Millar - an extraordinary life and a disappearing act | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The story of young West Coast entrepreneur Jake Millar is an extraordinary one of tragedy, success, money, the high life, and now, a disappearance. Transcript

item.title: Pacific unity is threatened in an ugly breakup | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The Pacific Islands Forum is facing unprecedented disruption at a time when it’s arguably needed the most, to present a united front on issues such as Covid and climate change. Transcript

item.title: Battling a rare disorder - and the health system | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description For those kiwis with rare disorders, it’s a battle against the health system to get treatment. Transcript

item.title: Re-shaping resource management | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description After 30 years the Resource Management Act - the unwieldy, development-stopping, strangely inadequate environmental legislation - is being reformed. Transcript

item.title: Selling off our national game | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Why would a massive international investment firm want a stake in New Zealand’s national game? And what could change if a deal with Silver Lake goes ahead? Transcript

item.title: When Australia and New Zealand take opposite sides | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Australia and New Zealand are supposedly cultural cousins, but this latest rift - over the return of a woman labelled a terrorist - shows we are drifting further and further apart. Transcript

item.title: Changing the bullying culture in sport | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Reviews, resignations, recriminations - New Zealand sport is rife with bullying accusations, particularly against women and girls. What’s being done to change the landscape? Transcript

item.title: Pulling the trigger on lockdown | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description What happens between the time when a lab worker finds a positive Covid-19 test in the community, and the Prime Minister announces another lockdown? Transcript

item.title: Why can't kiwi kids do maths? | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description New Zealand’s school kids are failing at maths - and other subjects too. What are we doing about addressing our educational gaps? Transcript

item.title: Too important to lose? The Infratil story | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description New Zealand sharemarket darling Infratil is in danger of being lost offshore, to Australia’s superfund. But is the company too important to lose? Transcript

item.title: Covid uncertainty over 2021 Polyfest sees top school pull out | The Detail

item.description: Podcast Description The debate about women speaking on the marae at Waitangi has lasted for years. There are customary rules, but it appears they are about to change. Transcript

item.title: The Detail's best of 2020 | The Detail

item.title: NZ Cricket has risen from the ashes | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description New Zealand cricket is in good shape, sharing the top of the honours board with Australia. But is it deserved? Transcript

item.title: Stress, lockdowns and changed eating habits | The Detail

item.description: Podcast Description The earth’s short of space and that’s affecting our customary expectations of how we bury our dead. Transcript

item.title: Tolerating child poverty as part of an economic strategy | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description We hear a lot about child poverty and lack of action on it - how bad is the situation really? Transcript

item.title: A glimpse into what went wrong in Christchurch | The Detail

item.title: Dementia research funding under threat | The Detail

item.title: Ombudsman's work is more than just about official information | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Emile Donovan sits down with the man charged with keeping the country’s civil servants in check. Transcript

item.title: The rise - and fall - and rise - of the Māori Party | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Māori politics is a story of rapid rises and sudden falls - and this year the Māori Party is back Transcript

item.title: The sport saddled with problems | The Detail

item.title: The fraught and divided US election | The Detail

item.title: What you need to know about election 2020's referendums | The Detail

item.description: Podcast Description Half of them are leaving or they want to leave …. investigative reporter Mel Reid talks about the extraordinary feedback she’s received from social workers to her stories on Oranga Tamariki. Transcript
