item.description: Podcast Description Three women’s world cups to be played in New Zealand over the next three years - but how well does this country really do when it comes to equity in sport? Transcript

item.title: Schools stripped of international cash going back to basics | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The Finance Minister says international students aren’t coming back to NZ any time soon. How will schools that have come to rely on the money they bring in now going to cut their cloth to fit? Transcript

item.title: From lockdown to recovery - tracking a small business during Covid | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The Detail tracks a Christchurch small business owner from the shock of lockdown to re-opening and recovery. Transcript

item.title: Clearing the streets of rough sleepers | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Lockdown temporarily eliminated rough sleeping in New Zealand - but what’s the long-term solution? Transcript

item.title: What first time voters want to know | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Elections are just around the corner - here’s what you want to know but have been too embarrassed to ask. Transcript

item.title: Our prison remand crisis | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Remand prisoners are kept in a waiting room for danger - and they make up more than a third of the prison population. How did this situation turn into a crisis? Transcript

item.title: Max Abbott and more - sexual harassment at a top university | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Much-lauded mental health expert Dr Max Abbott has resigned after being outed for sexual harassment. But his case is just the tip of what’s going on. Transcript

item.title: The minor parties - their place in our political arena | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description What’s the point in voting for a party that is never going to take a seat in Parliament? Well, there are plenty of reasons, say our guests today. Transcript

item.title: Are Rocket Lab's enterprises in our national interest? | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description It’s one of our most successful companies - but how much do we know about what Rocket Lab is carrying into outer space, and who it’s carrying it for? Transcript

item.title: Using infrastructure to boost the economy | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Infrastructure is such a boring word - but what’s happening now to boost our economy through shovel-ready projects will change our quality of life. Transcript

item.title: Tackling New Zealand rugby's financial woes | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Advertising deals down the drain, ticket sales from international games gone - why New Zealand rugby is in a fraught space financially. Transcript

item.title: Re-building our health system | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The new Health and Disability Review is said to be the biggest shake up of the health system in a generation - so what was wrong with it in the first place? Transcript

item.title: Tearing down statues - and revisiting our histories | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The statues are being torn down, and history re-written. Are we destroying the past, or correcting the record? Transcript

item.title: Trapped migrant workers - NZ's new underclass | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description New Zealand is developing a new underclass of desperate people - migrants who no longer have any work and can’t get home; and temporary visa holders trapped outside the borders when they snapped shut. Transcript

item.title: What happened while you were sleeping in? | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The world didn’t completely stop while we were in lockdown. Here’s a summary of what else happened while we were tuned to the 1pm Ashley and Jacinda show. Transcript

item.title: Why is it taking so long to install fishing cameras? | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Cameras on fishing boats have been promised for years, and were due to roll out on 1000 vessels on 1 July - now they’ve been quietly put on ice, again. Transcript

item.title: Why Armed Response Teams struck the wrong note in NZ | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Armed Response Teams are dead in the water, with the new police commissioner reading the room when it comes to arming Kiwi cops. Transcript

item.title: NZ's new internet laws - sensible censorship? | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The World Wide Web is an international phenomenon with few rules, and no one stepping up as global sheriff. Can New Zealand’s new internet legislation have an impact on its worst excesses without over-censorship? Transcript

item.title: The future of film in New Zealand | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description New Zealand’s about ready to go back to the movies. Trouble is, what movies? And is this worldwide pandemic a chance to up our game in the industry? Transcript

item.title: Why superannuation is political kryptonite | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The Super dilemma - how can New Zealand afford the weight of future pensions without raising the superannuation age? Transcript

item.title: An insight into George Floyd's world | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description An African-American pastor from George Floyd’s community gives The Detail a special insight into what’s happening there - and gives us hope for the future. Transcript

item.title: Why is Transmission Gully such a troubled project? | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Why is it so hard to build a coastal bypass road north of Wellington? Transmission Gully has been in the planning stages for over a century - and it’s hit more hiccups. Transcript

item.title: The big Kiwi company hanging on to pandemic refunds | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description A company many consider a national icon is refusing to refund hundreds of millions of dollars in customer cash. Why is Air New Zealand holding on to airfares for cancelled trips? Transcript

item.title: The health of our coastal waters is in peril | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Efforts to protect our coastal waters from further degradation are piecemeal, slow and amount to a drop in an ocean of problems. How do we bring life back to the sea? Transcript

item.title: Battling lockdown fatigue | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The Detail catches up with Sharon Brettkelly’s sister and her family, still - after three months - in lockdown in California. So much has happened, and nothing has happened. Transcript

item.title: Changing our lives in a post-Covid world | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description How can New Zealand hang on to the silver linings of lockdown? The quiet, the lack of air pollution, the family bike rides, working from home, the kinder politics. Or will we quickly return to normal? Transcript

item.title: Women on boards - why NZ needs a kick | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description New Zealand is not as egalitarian as it likes to think it is when it comes to the boardroom. One of our top directors explains why we should introduce quotas for women; and an expert on the issue tells us why we shouldn’t. Transcript

item.title: Tip-toeing around China | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Aggressively expanding, and sensitive to diplomatic slights, China is making sure a good crisis is not going to waste. Transcript

item.title: Mixed messages and confusion - travel after Covid | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description With many nations’ borders still closed, global tourism is going to be slow to crank up. Who is leading the way and what are countries doing to entice back visitors? Transcript

item.title: What's up with Wellington? | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Wellington is dealing with failing infrastructure and pandemic problems at a time when councillors are sniping at each other and the new mayor is losing his political battles. Transcript

item.title: Our contact tracing app - how effective will it be? | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The government’s finally introduced a contact tracing app, but questions remain over its effectiveness, how transparent the process has been, and inconsistencies involved. Transcript

item.title: Why conspiracy theories thrive in times of crisis | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Attacks on 5G cellphone towers around the world are based on rumours and theories that just aren’t true. Why has this pandemic spawned so many widely-believed conspiracies? Transcript

item.description: Podcast Description Pope Francis, Mark Zuckerberg, Bishop Desmond Tutu and Gareth Morgan all want it - a Universal Basic Income. What is it, and how would it work? Transcript

item.title: The race for a Covid-19 vaccine | The Detail

item.title: Queenstown - pretty, empty | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description A look at Queenstown’s economic coronavirus bloodbath - and what it will take to recover. Transcript

item.title: Tauranga - the downsides of a population explosion | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Tauranga is one of the fastest growing areas of New Zealand but with that is growing gang war and a massive rates hike. Transcript

item.title: How a young white supremacist did a radical u-turn | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Caleb Cain got lost in an internet world of white supremacism. What happened to get him to make such a radical u-turn that he’s now preaching from the other side of the page? Transcript

item.title: The future of flying looks grim | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Tourism and travel are in free fall. Our biggest export earner is dead. Will the industry ever fully recover? Transcript

item.title: Technology and the big shift to working from home | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Just about anyone who’s still working, is working from home. We look at the social and technical issues behind the big shift to your new “office”. Transcript

item.title: The weekend warriors hit by heavy-handed doping laws | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Is New Zealand’s sporting watchdog being too heavy-handed in banning weekend warriors who take substances for vanity reasons? Transcript

item.title: China and Covid-19 - rewriting the facts | The Detail

item.title: What happens to a family stuck together in quarantine? | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Like millions in the Bay Area of California, Sharon Brettkelly’s sister and her family are in virtual lockdown. We Skype them to discover how they found themselves stuck in the house, and how they’re coping. Transcript

item.title: Keeping anxiety in check amidst uncertainty | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description How do you manage your anxiety in a time of uncertainty like now? And when does concern turn into irrational fear? Transcript

item.title: Is COVID-19 the iceberg that will sink the cruise ship industry? | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Ships banned, quarantined, and shunned by the bug-phobic - is the coronavirus the iceberg that will sink the cruise industry? Transcript

item.description: Podcast Description Hugely intelligent, insatiably curious, kea are more endangered than kiwi - and their bold antics are partly why the alpine parrot’s population is shrinking. Transcript

item.description: Podcast Description The country’s first case of smuggled bear bile has gone through the courts - but it’s far from the only example of trading in endangered wildlife New Zealand authorities are dealing with. Transcript

item.title: Did the millions raised for mosque victims actually get to them? | The Detail

item.title: What is the circular economy? | The Detail

item.description: Podcast Description Loot Boxes are the video version of bubble gum cards - you buy them while gaming, without knowing what prize you’re going to get. But critics say they’re opening a door for children to gamble. Transcript

item.title: The murky, confusing world of US political races | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The US Democratic primary races are incomprehensible to most of us - so why are they so gripping? Transcript

item.title: Is cancel culture repressing freedom of thought? | The Detail

item.title: How vulnerable is NZ to extreme right populism? | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Europe is seeing a rapid rise of extremist parties in government - in countries with similar political systems as ours. Why isn’t that happening here? Or is it? Transcript

item.description: Podcast Description The Serious Fraud Office is once again investigating a headline-producing case. But is it prosecuting the right crimes - or just the ones it knows it will win? Transcript

item.title: Setting aside the Moriori myth | The Detail

item.title: The secret deal that's causing a big stink in Mataura | The Detail

item.title: Waitangi Museum tells the stories of a nation's birth | The Detail

item.title: Our Top 10 of The Detail this year | The Detail

item.title: How attempted censorship by Trump troops backfired | The Detail

item.title: Where in the world is our defence force? | The Detail

item.title: The beauty and the menace of Whakaari | The Detail

item.title: Is the Provincial Growth Fund making a difference? | The Detail

item.title: Hope is fading for the Kiwi nurse missing in Syria | The Detail

item.title: The Tiwai Point aluminium smelter bluff | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description How real is the threat to close the Tiwai Point aluminium smelter, with the loss of 1000 jobs? Transcript

item.title: The festival organisers who now have to plan for disaster | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Organisers of New Zealand’s big cultural festivals have another item on their list of things to do - after March 15, security has become a major factor. Transcript

item.title: Wiring up an orchestra | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description How do RNZ engineers wire up an orchestra ready for radio play? With a lot of microphones, for a start. Transcript

item.title: Salvaging the SkyCity convention centre | The Detail

item.title: Where is NZ First heading next? | The Detail

item.description: Podcast Description Wellington’s Mayor-elect, whose majority is hanging by a thread, didn’t just (probably) get there because he was partly bankrolled by Sir Peter Jackson. Transcript

item.description: Podcast Description Drug testing volunteers who set up at festivals and events are treading a legal grey area, held up by politicians with morals. Transcript

item.description: Podcast Description Should we believe the Rugby World Cup’s claims that the sport has taken over Japan? Transcript

item.title: Stats NZ mines your cellphone data - should you be worried? | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Stats NZ has upped the ante when it comes to data collection - should we be worried? Transcript

item.title: Is it time for New Zealand to push through anti-slavery laws? | The Detail

item.title: The shocking story of what happens to refugees in Italy | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The shocking story of what happens when refugees land in Italy, and the connection with your spaghetti Bolognese. Transcript

item.title: Excluded from an inclusion conference | The Detail

item.title: Forestry companies buying vast amounts of New Zealand's land | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Journalist, Kate Newton breaks down her investigation into land ownership in Aotearoa. Transcript

item.title: How New Zealand is adjusting to its ageing population | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Is New Zealand keeping up with its ageing population; as the population grows older, how will we provide for them? Transcript

item.title: Australia looking to sting back in battle over mānuka honey | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Australian beekeepers are staking their claim over products branded as mānuka honey. Transcript

item.title: Is workplace bullying on the rise - or just no longer acceptable? | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Is workplace bullying on the rise - or have we finally realised that it’s not acceptable? Transcript

item.title: The story behind the sex abuser at the sexual abuse inquiry | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The story behind the discovery that a sex offender was attending meetings of survivors of sexual abuse. Transcript

item.title: The pardoning of Rua Kēnana - pacifist and prophet | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Prophet and pacifist Rua Kēnana is to be pardoned - who was he, and how is this related to the government’s announcement on teaching New Zealand history in schools? Transcript

item.title: Why global trade disruption is worrying our wine industry | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Our $1.83 billion wine industry is being caught up in global trade wars that insiders describe as ‘fundamentally concerning’. Transcript

item.title: Farmers down in the dumps - and dragging down the country | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Rural confidence is at its lowest point in three years, with farmers saying they’re under siege from all sides. Transcript

item.title: E-scooters - should we ban them or embrace them? | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description E-scooters have hit New Zealand’s cities with a bang - often literally. Are they good news or bad news? And are they here to stay? Transcript

item.title: Sudden ditching of Te Papa North plan stuns Auckland | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Years of planning for an Auckland arm of our national museum that would showcase much of the country’s Māori and Pacific taonga have been dashed, in a decision that’s stunned those behind it. Transcript

item.title: Changing names without changing places | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description People get fired up when it’s suggested the name of their town is changed - so what’s involved in re-naming a place? Transcript

item.title: New Zealand's rampant meth culture | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description New Zealand’s demand for meth is rampant - and organised crime gangs are stepping up their efforts to get it into the country. Transcript

item.title: Sophie Pascoe is the Michael Phelps of paralympians | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Paralympic swimmer Sophie Pascoe is so good, the only person she has to beat is herself. Transcript

item.title: The gender equity report that shocked a bank | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Westpac NZ, a bank proud of its equity record, has revealed shocking figures on its own gender pay gap. It’s front-footing the issue but says it can’t change things on its own. Transcript

item.title: What's behind south Auckland's recent crime spike? | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description What’s going on in south Auckland that once again has its suburbs on the wrong side of news headlines? Transcript

item.title: Pacific teams the have-nots of world rugby | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description They have all the flair in the world, look like they’re having fun, and their fans are the most fervent - but in spite of being neighbours to the All Blacks, the Pacific teams are the have-nots of the Rugby World Cup. Transcript

item.title: Taika Waititi is the toast of Toronto | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Taika Waititi has been the talk of the Toronto International Film Festival for his film Jojo Rabbit - a controversial passion project that’s being both lauded and slated. Transcript

item.title: Labour's badly bungled sexual assault investigation | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description A look at the handling - or mis-handling - of sexual assault allegations within the Labour Party. Transcript

item.title: Why is Japan still slaughtering whales? | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Japan has returned to commercial whaling for the first time in 30 years - but it’s sticking to its own territorial waters. Is this why the world’s gone quiet over it? Transcript

item.title: Eco-flying is far, far away | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description With 4.5 billion air passengers last year, and that number set to double in less than 20 years, how on earth are airlines going to help save the planet? Transcript

item.title: Is post-truth politics creeping into New Zealand? | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description We’ve seen ‘post-truth’ politics flourish in the US and Britain - are New Zealand politicians also starting to adopt the tactic of ‘alternative facts’? Transcript

item.title: Getting rich from lending to the poor | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description How the government plans to crack down on people who are getting rich from lending to the poor. Transcript

item.title: Fighting over Kashmir | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Kashmir is a region of snow capped mountains and idyllic landscapes - as well as barbed wire and army round-ups. Tension has risen again as India moves in on the nation’s autonomy. Transcript

item.title: The silent health problems that cripple women | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Tens of thousands of girls and women have to put up with chronic pain for years - because their issues are played down or deemed non-urgent. Transcript

item.title: How exposed is New Zealand politics to foreign influence? | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Can rich foreigners buy political influence in New Zealand? And are our rules over donations to political parties too easy to get around? Transcript

item.title: Swamp kauri plunder a tale of misadventure | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The boom times for the controversial swamp kauri trade appear to be declining - just as a Northland environmental group wins a David and Goliath battle to stop the region being pillaged. Transcript

item.title: When tourist spots are so hot the residents get burnt | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Imagine a bunch of tourists walking into your house uninvited. It’s not unusual for the residents of Dunedin’s Baldwin St, one of many overcrowded attractions in New Zealand and around the world. Transcript

item.title: Experiments with LSD | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description An Auckland scientist is planning a world-first study into the effects of micro-dosing a drug that entered notoriety in the 1970s - LSD. Transcript

item.title: Local body boredom - why every council election is a fizzer | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Local body candidate billboards are everywhere right now, but they don’t necessarily translate into awareness. Why do so few people vote in an election that affects everyone? Transcript

item.title: Anti-environmental policies blamed for Amazon fires | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description There has been an 80 percent increase in fires in Brazil’s Amazon jungle in the last year and president Jair Bolsonaro is being blamed. Transcript

item.title: Is it time to re-visit our GE rules? | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Are our genetic engineering rules keeping New Zealand safe - or holding us back? Transcript

item.title: We are forgetting the Holocaust | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description It used to be a prevalent part of history - six million Jewish people were killed in World War II’s holocaust. But new polls show we are forgetting the facts. Transcript

item.title: Cracking open the secretive petrol retailing industry | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description High petrol prices in New Zealand is a merry go round of blame - will the Commerce Commission’s new report lay open retailers’ books and help drive prices down? Transcript

item.title: How Big Pharma operates in New Zealand | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Heartbreaking stories of cancer sufferers who need expensive and unfunded drugs abound. But some of those stories are helped into the spotlight by the drug companies that will also benefit. Transcript

item.title: The unlikely freedom fighters of Hong Kong | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Hong Kong residents would prefer to concentrate on their business activities - but they realise they’re losing their freedom to a Chinese government that’s not remote enough for them, and they’re angry about it. Transcript

item.title: Banks behaving badly | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Why do banks get away with behaving so badly? There’s been a run of activity lately that raises questions about whose side your banker is really on. Transcript

item.title: Why getting the census count right was so important | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Getting the census right is important, not just for electoral boundaries but for a host of government funding decisions. Why has it been such a disaster this time around? Transcript

item.title: Gene editing scientist was no lone rogue | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The Chinese scientist who shook the world by announcing he’d gene edited twin baby girls appears to have unfairly been labelled a rogue - it turns out he had a 60-strong circle of trust. Transcript

item.title: The ABCs of the OCR | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Newsroom’s Bernard Hickey explains the latest OCR drop, what it means, and predicts its direction a year out. Transcript

item.title: The Pacific's plastic catastrophe | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Meet the man who is swimming through the Great Pacific Garbage Patch in an effort to draw the world’s attention to the amount of plastic in the ocean. Transcript

item.title: Shoots of discontent in the Green Party | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The Green Party, in holding up the coalition government, has tasted real power - but some of the party’s grass roots members don’t like what’s being done with it. Transcript

item.title: A golf star in the rough | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Lydia Ko, superstar of golf, a few years ago had the world at her feet. Now she’s in a slump, and that whole world has seen fit to pile on the criticism. Transcript

item.title: Aussies toughen up on deportees | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Australia looks likely to toughen up even further on its deportation of New Zealanders who’ve committed minor crimes. But once they’re “home” - the problems get worse. Transcript

item.title: Discomfort over Commission secrecy | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Questions are being raised over the Royal Commission of Inquiry into the Christchurch mosque shootings - is it transparent and inclusive enough? Transcript

item.title: What's the point in trying to save a dying species? | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Some of the species conservationists are trying to save seem determined not to survive. So why are we sinking hundreds of millions into trying to rescue them? Transcript

item.title: Where Aotearoa lets its kids down | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description A new $42 million project is looking to address New Zealand’s education inequality - a system where Māori are failing, and are “leaving their culture at the gate.” Transcript

item.title: Peter Ellis and the Christchurch creche case | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Peter Ellis has always vowed he was innocent of the child sex charges he was jailed for in 1993. Now he’s dying of cancer - and the Supreme Court has given him leave to appeal his convictions. Transcript

item.title: Getting our heads around Facebook money | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description Facebook’s new currency plans were barely more than a press statement before they came under fire from US lawmakers. Why do people hate the idea, and is it likely to fly? Transcript

item.title: How to sink $4.4 billion underground | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The Detail today takes you underground to have a look at progress on New Zealand’s first underground rail system. Transcript

item.title: Ihumātao explained | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description The history of Ihumātao is long, complicated and fraught - and there may not be any way of resolving the issue. Transcript

item.title: Planting a billion trees by 2028 | The Detail
item.description: Podcast Description How on earth is New Zealand going to get a billion trees planted by 2028? And why are some farmers campaigning against the scheme? Transcript
